title: Hollande Appoints New Labor Minister
content:
PARIS¿French President Franç ois Hollande on Wednesday appointed Myriam El Khomri as labor minister, opting for a candidate with limited experience of government to tackle his main challenge: stem the rise in unemployment before elections in 2017. 

Mr. Hollande's office announced the decision to appoint the 37 year old, who has served as junior minister for towns since August 2014, after Franç ois Rebsamen left the labor ministry to become mayor of Dijon. 

Moroccan-born Ms. El Khomri will be the third labor minister since Mr. Hollande came to office in May 2012. Over that period, unemployment has risen steadily to record levels, despite a stream of initiatives from state-sponsored jobs to sweeping tax cuts for employers to encourage hiring. 

Ms. Khomri will shoulder a huge responsibility for Mr. Hollande as the Socialist president has said he won't run for re-election in 2017 unless unemployment begins to fall. The latest figures from Eurostat show unemployment in France rose edged up to 10.4% in July from 10.3%, despite declining in the eurozone as a whole. 

As well as the overall challenge of bringing down unemployment, Ms. El Khomri will be charged with examining possible changes to France's complex labor code and initiating negotiations with labor unions over costly welfare benefits. 

Before joining the government, Ms. Khomri held several posts at the Paris town council, specializing in security, crime prevention and child protection.
